I've been a film critic for The Front Page newspaper for the past ten years. Before that, I wrote reviews for other newspapers, magazines, and radio stations. My first job as a critic was at The Front Page, where I met Tom Seaton, the arts editor. He had a unique idea - to have a team of critics cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would discuss our choices over lunch, with occasional guests joining us. It was a dream come true to be part of a new newspaper. However, the team idea didn't work out, and we ended up working individually by phone.

I chose to focus on film criticism because it's what I enjoy most. I wouldn't want to review every film that comes out, as that would get boring. Instead, I write a weekly article on one film, which gives me the freedom to explore different themes and ideas. My role is not to tell people what to watch or not to watch. Instead, I try to provide an argument about the film. I don't feel responsible for being 'right' or 'wrong' about a movie. My goal is to share my thoughts and opinions, and I'm not a judge.

Melanie has had some ups and downs in her triathlon career. She once entered the National Championships and finished nowhere, but she didn't give up. She has also had to overcome some mistakes, like going the wrong way during a race and having to cycle 20 kilometers extra.

Despite the challenges, Melanie is determined to keep going. She is already a top junior triathlete and is hoping to compete in the World Championships in New Zealand. She needs to buy a new bike to help her train and is trying to convince her parents to help her out.

However, her intense training schedule has made it difficult for her to have a social life. She doesn't have time for parties or hanging out with friends. Instead, she focuses on her training and talks to other athletes about their times and progress.

Melanie wants to keep pushing herself to new limits and is considering entering even tougher events than triathlons. She is looking for someone her age to train with, but so far, she hasn't found anyone.

It's the way collections change hands that fascinates me. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet can be very valuable. As certain objects become popular, their value increases.

Some old toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot of money, as long as you still have the original boxes and contents. I, unfortunately, threw mine away!

In a lumberyard by a lake, there was an old building with soft sawdust piled up all around it. The sawdust was so high that it reached the lake. One afternoon, Michael and his friends decided to climb up to the roof of the old building. They sat down and looked out at the lake. Michael said, 'I dare you to jump down!' He jumped first and landed safely in the sawdust. His friends were hesitant at first, but eventually they all jumped down and laughed together. They spent the rest of the afternoon lying on the sawdust, telling jokes and having fun.

Later, one of Michael's friends suggested they jump down again. This time, Michael was the only one who didn't want to. He was scared and didn't know why. His friends teased him and called him a coward. Michael tried to convince himself to jump, but he couldn't. He stayed on the roof for a long time, feeling ashamed and alone. Eventually, he slipped off the roof and fell onto the sawdust. He lay there for a while, feeling sorry for himself.

When he got home, his stepmother was angry because he was late for dinner. She told him he was old enough to get home on time and that he should stay in if he didn't want to come home. Michael was still feeling sad and embarrassed, and he hardly heard his stepmother's words. He was still thinking about his friends and how they had laughed at him.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B2 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Chocolate has a long history that started in South America. Today, it's a big business worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter, which is 8% of all chocolate sold. Christmas is the only time when people eat more chocolate. The process of making chocolate began a long time ago, over 3,000 years ago, when the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans grew the cacao tree. The tree is an evergreen plant that grows in many parts of the world. The fruit of the tree has 20-40 seeds, which become cacao beans when dried. These beans can be used to make chocolate.

In the past, the Aztecs used cacao beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in the Aztec language. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar. For a long time, people in Europe didn't know about the drink, but eventually, chocolate houses were set up in big cities where people could go to drink it.

In the 19th century, a man named CJ van Houten invented chocolate powder, which made it easier to make chocolate. Later, a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, created the first chocolate bar. A Swiss company added milk to the process, and milk chocolate was born.

In the past, British chocolate was made by French companies, but then Cadbury created their famous Dairy Milk bar. The company even named their factory Bournville, which means 'town' in French. The bar became popular because of clever advertising that linked it to healthy milk from the English countryside.

Today, people in the UK eat about four chocolate bars a week, which means manufacturers have to find new ways to attract customers. One way is by making chocolate into different products, like ice cream or soft drinks. At the same time, cacao farmers are still feeling the effects of a drop in cocoa bean prices in the 1980s. Many small-scale farmers were forced out of business. So, next time you eat a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grew the cacao beans.'

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends most of her time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and does research on the chemistry of the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she's not teaching, she goes on underwater expeditions to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a special vehicle that's like a small car, but for the ocean. She dives down 3 kilometers to the ocean floor and stays there for 16 hours. 

The vehicle is very small, so she has to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. If something goes wrong, she can press a panic button and a small escape vessel will be released. It will quickly take her back to the surface. 

Rachel has made six dives so far. Last year, she went on a trip with a Russian team to a site with many underwater volcanoes. They were studying how a big hole would affect the volcanoes. When she's not at sea, Rachel works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She teaches and does research on underwater volcanoes, which she calls "black smokers." 

These are really hot and can be frightening. Rachel was once scared when there was an explosion during one of her dives. But she's always excited to explore the ocean floor and see the volcanoes. She feels lucky to be able to do this work and see things that no one else has seen before.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the B2 level:

I was tired, hungry, and dirty after my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted from all the traveling, and my mind was overwhelmed by foreign languages, timetables, and currencies. I thought, "Never again!" But the next year, and the year after, I said the same thing when I stepped off the train and back onto my own soil. As a young person under 25, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a month with just one train ticket.

Carrying my backpack and sleeping on trains made me appreciate the simple things in life. I learned to be more wasteful, but in a fun way. I would get rid of old socks and books when I was done with them. This carefree attitude is what Inter-Rail is all about.

My friends and I thought the Inter-Rail ticket was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we soon discovered that we could travel to other countries without extra cost. We visited many places, but we mostly focused on the most obvious sights. This was our chance to escape the usual tourist routes and do something different.

We were proud of the fact that we didn't bother to see everything. We just wanted to have a good time and enjoy the journey. We shared our experiences with other travelers, and we were all excited to be exploring Europe together.

The thrill of travel comes from seeing a place for the first time. When the train arrives at the station, you see the city with your own eyes, and it's like it's brand new. Only by experiencing Europe firsthand can you really understand what it's like. Everyone knows what Europe is like, but it's not the same until you see it for yourself. That's why other people's holiday photos are often boring. The train trip may not teach you anything new, but it's a valuable experience.

Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives you the chance to explore it. In our case, it took us a while to realize just how big it was.<|eot_id|>

'Lost luggage is a common problem for travelers. Imagine arriving at an airport and discovering that your suitcase is nowhere to be found. You may have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline finds your luggage. This can be especially frustrating if you're traveling to a different climate zone or to a place far from home.

Airline companies don't usually reveal how many bags they lose, but it's a fact that travelers will eventually experience this problem. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it's impossible to guarantee that your luggage will be on the same flight as you.

The airline's baggage system has a few flaws. For example, they require passengers to check in too early, which can cause delays. There are also minimum connecting times between flights, but these can be too short. Sometimes, flights are delayed due to security checks or air traffic problems, which can cause the baggage system to fail.

Additionally, there's always the risk of human error or accidents, especially at busy airports. For instance, London's Heathrow airport is one of the busiest, with over 41 million passengers passing through each year. Even at efficient airports like Amsterdam or Singapore, mistakes can happen.

To avoid losing your luggage, it's a good idea to choose direct flights whenever possible and check in early. If you have to change planes, try to fly with the same airline and allow extra time for your connection. Make sure to label your luggage clearly with your home and holiday addresses, and don't forget to include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, you should report it to the airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report before leaving the airport.'

Fun Island - The Burns Family

We visited Fun Island and were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger kids, with rides like the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's even a special ride for little ones. The older kids loved the scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! We thought the park was a bit lacking in atmosphere, but the staff were friendly and helpful.

Wonderland - The McMillan Family

We visited Wonderland and were impressed. The park has something for everyone, from the Mountain Train to the ferris wheel. The older kids loved driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and enjoyed the clean and well-organized park.

Adventure World - The Jeffree Family

We spent seven hours at Adventure World and still didn't see everything. The kids loved the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line, which was a bit scary. The park is well-designed, so queuing for rides isn't boring. The staff are great and the park is spotless.

The Great Park - The Langridge Family

We visited The Great Park, which is perfect for younger kids. The rides aren't too scary, and we all enjoyed Exotic Travels, a boat ride that gets more exciting towards the end. We queued for half an hour for Lightning River, but it was over before we knew it!

Fantasy World - The Break-all Family

Fantasy World lives up to its name, with Europe's tallest roller-coaster and many other rides. The kids loved the Rocket and the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 metres above the ground. We thought the staff were a bit mixed, but overall, it was a great day out."

Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She and her husband moved to the countryside because they wanted a better work-life balance. She works from home, which saves her money on office rent. She has four employees and a turnover of over £200,000 a year.

Maggy Sasanow is a designer who works from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there weren't any jobs available in the countryside. So, she started her own business designing greetings cards. She sells her cards to museums and has a good reputation for being cheaper than other artists.

Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She started eight years ago and had a lot of success, but then the economy declined and she had to lay off her employees. Now, she works from home with the help of her husband and a few part-time workers.

Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside for financial reasons and to be closer to nature. She works with authors and artists from all over the world and has to be disciplined to shut the office door.

Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She started making fruit cakes at home and soon got requests from friends and relatives. She now employs six people and has a turnover of £250,000 a year."

'The National Trust is an organisation that works to protect the British countryside. I visited the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talked to Gareth Roberts, a warden who takes care of the beautiful areas owned by the Trust. Gareth thinks that to be a good warden, you need common sense and the ability to work well with people. He needs to deal with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders.

Gareth grew up on a farm on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked there until he got married. When he applied for the warden job, he was one of about 80 people who applied. He got the job because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he didn't have any formal training.

Gareth's farming background is helpful because he can understand the problems of farmers and deal with them on an equal level. He also knows how to handle the physical demands of the job, such as building fences and planting trees.

Gareth has learned more about nature conservation since he started working for the Trust. He used to collect flowers, butterflies, and birds' nests as a child, but he realises now that farming has affected the countryside. He thinks that farmers were just following government advice, and that conservationists and farmers can work together.

Gareth's job involves conservation, making sure people can visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He enjoys seeing projects finished and working with the public, except for some people who are not very nice to him. If you have common sense and like working outdoors, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth, but there might not be a job available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time.'

'The Netball Captain

In our series on women in sport, we met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. She's been training hard for the World Championships next month. When I talked to her, she'd just finished a day of teaching at a local school and a training session in the car park. "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don't notice anything else," she said. "I might see cars slowing down, but that's all."

Kendra's whole life is now about being at her best for the Championships. She's on a strict schedule to get fit for the big event. This is her fourth time playing in the World Championships, and it's going to be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries taking part.

"We'll have the support of our home crowd, which is amazing," she said. "And it's important to show that netball is a popular sport in this country. We'll have more pressure than usual, but that's okay. We're used to playing in front of big crowds."

Their first game is against Barbados, and it's right after the opening ceremony. "We've beaten them before, but they're a tough team," Kendra said. "They have a lot of skill."

The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the World Championships will be tough. "You have to give it your all every day, with no rest between games. And you can still win even if you lose the first game. But in the Championships, there's only one chance, so you have to be ready."

In the 15 years she's been playing at the top level, the sport has become faster and more competitive. "Players are more aggressive now," she said. "But once the game is over, we all become friends again."

Netball is also using new methods to test players' fitness. "We all have to think and train like world-class players," Kendra said. "As captain, I need to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I support and encourage the rest of the team."

Kendra has always planned her netball career carefully. She's decided that this will be her last big competition as a player. She'll probably coach young players in the future, but for now, her focus is on this event. When she leads her team out onto the court for the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'<|eot_id|>

' SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS How to help a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always clear how to develop and encourage their gift. Some parents may not recognize and respond to their child's needs until they become frustrated and difficult to manage. Most schools are good at helping children who are very good at academic subjects, but those with musical talent need special support that may not be available in a regular school, especially if music is not a main focus. Children with exceptional musical ability, as well as those whose parents or teachers encourage their talent, may benefit from a specialist music school. There are five music schools in Britain that offer a special environment for children aged 7-18 to develop their skills under the guidance of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend most of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons, orchestras, and theory. They also have private practice rooms and spend some time on core subjects like English, maths, and science. The schools are independent and have small classes with a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which means they spend their formative years with others who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. The schools are expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year. Additionally, not all parents want their children to board at school, especially at a young age. Some directors of the schools question the wisdom of admitting children as young as 7 to such an intense environment. They stress that their goal is to produce well-rounded individuals. Setting musically gifted children apart from others can cause stress, and some may lose their early signs of musical ability in their teenage years. The schools keep a close eye on each student's progress and offer help if needed.

Some former students feel they benefited greatly from the high-quality music education, but others express concerns about the limited academic program. Many musically gifted students are also highly intelligent and can handle academic pressure, but may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met. It may be better to wait until the child is old enough to make their own decisions before considering a specialist education. Those who are equally gifted academically may do well in a less specialized environment, such as a school with a strong music department or by combining regular school with music training at a junior music college. However, this option is not practical for families living outside of major cities.'<|eot_id|>

Martin Brown - Journalist

We were working on a project and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unpredictable, but when the train arrived, hundreds of people got on board. We even saw people climbing onto the roof! At night, the train passed through beautiful landscapes, like a dream.

Arisu Mezuki - Actress

I didn't grow up with trains, as I was raised in Singapore and Cyprus. I didn't see many trains until I was a teenager. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old disused track that volunteers had restored. I loved the experience and went back last year. Everything was still the same - even the old gas lights on the platform.'

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B2:

Are you trying to get your writing published? If so, you're probably wondering where to send your work. Many people ask me, "I've written a story/book, can you tell me who to send it to?" First, you need to research the market and learn about publishers. This means reading widely and finding out what kinds of writing are popular at the moment. You can do this by visiting your local library and bookshops, and reading different types of publications.

It's also important to practice your writing skills. Whatever you write, you need to know what kind of writing is in demand. This means reading a lot and keeping up to date with new publications and changing trends. If you're not sure what you want to write about, start by finding out which magazines publish the type of writing you're interested in. For example, if you like writing love stories, find out which magazines use this type of content and read some recent issues.

When you're ready to send your work out, be prepared for rejection. It's normal to get rejected at first, even if you're a good writer. The key is to keep writing and improving your skills. Don't be discouraged if your work is rejected - it's all part of the process. Instead, use the feedback you receive to make your writing better and keep writing.

It's also important to be patient and persistent. Don't send out your work until it's ready, and don't be afraid to ask for help or join a writing group to get feedback and support. Remember, every successful writer has had to deal with rejection and criticism at some point. The most important thing is to keep writing and believe in yourself.

I was waiting for my train at the Baltimore railway station. It was the last day of a bad year, and I was heading to Philadelphia. The station was busier than I expected. Elderly couples with suitcases were sitting on the benches, and groups of college students were scattered around with their bags. A well-dressed man was walking around, talking to people. He approached a woman and asked if she was going to Philadelphia. She said no, but he didn't ask anyone else. Then he came to me and asked if I was going to Philadelphia. I thought I might like to talk to him, but he just moved on.

He went to an old lady and asked if she was going to Philadelphia. When she said no, he didn't say anything and walked away. I was curious about what was going on. He seemed stressed. He asked another woman if she was going to Philadelphia, and she said yes. He asked her for a favour, but she seemed hesitant.

He told her that his daughter was leaving for a study year abroad from Philadelphia, but she had forgotten her passport. He had put her on a train earlier that morning and was now trying to get her passport from someone in the station. The woman was sympathetic, but I thought it was a strange story. Why didn't he go himself? He said he couldn't leave his wife alone, as she was in a wheelchair. I didn't think this was a good excuse.

I noticed that he was holding a padded envelope, which seemed suspicious. I thought to myself, "Be careful, lady!"

'I'm John Moore, the owner of a restaurant. I've written about my relationship with my son Gary, who's a famous TV chef. I believe everyone deserves a chance in life. My son Gary was given his chance in cooking, and I was given the chance to run a restaurant. When I saw the restaurant, it was in a bad state, but it was perfect for me. It reminded me of my childhood, when my mother worked in a factory and I was left alone. That's why I wanted to make sure my family had time together. My wife took care of the children and did the accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped our children, Gary and Joe, become confident. They would often talk to our regular customers from a young age. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a lively child who loved to play. He even jumped into our corner bath like a swimming pool when he was seven and knocked himself out! As he grew older, he started working for pocket money, doing odd jobs and then helping out in the kitchen every weekend. He was very disciplined and would often get up before me in the morning. I was proud to see him helping out in the family business.

Gary wasn't very academic, but he was amazing in the kitchen. By the time he was 15, he was as good as any of the other chefs, and sometimes he was even in charge. He could produce over 100 meals by himself. I knew then that he would go into catering. When he did his work experience at school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. Who knows what will happen to his cooking if his music takes off!

My advice to Gary is to focus on one thing at a time. He needs to chase his dreams, but not too many of them at once. I told him that if he doesn't achieve his goals by the age of 30, it might be too late. Gary went to catering college at 17 and quickly proved himself to be an exceptional cook. He's now a successful TV chef, and I'm extremely proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. He's taken his opportunities and made the most of them.'<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text, suitable for a learner of level B2 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Dolphins are loved by many people. We enjoy watching them in marinas, films, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, their situation is very worrying. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of the species.

Dolphins are intelligent and sensitive animals that allow us to imagine a free and wonderful life in the sea. This love for dolphins has been encouraged by TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest. However, these happy portrayals hide the reality of dolphins' lives in polluted and overfished seas.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises has decreased by up to 89,000. You might expect such popular animals to be protected by law and cared for in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and the lack of plans to protect them may become one of the biggest wildlife disasters of our time.

There are 40 different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In European waters, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose, and harbour porpoise dolphins. The first two are usually found far out in the open sea, while the last two are often seen near European coasts.

Bottlenose dolphins are social and used to be found near the Channel coast and in British river mouths. However, their numbers have decreased, and the few remaining ones show signs of stress. The reasons for this decline are complex and difficult to determine.

Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks worldwide, also threatens porpoises and dolphins. This is because porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish in one area are removed, they may not survive. They are also at risk of getting caught in fishermen's nets, which can be invisible to them.

In recent years, many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornish beaches, with signs of injury caused by getting caught in nets. Dolphins can also store waste and substances in their bodies, such as pesticides, which can harm them and their young.

Human disturbance is another threat to dolphins. They live in groups and receive information about their environment through sound. Noise pollution from ships, oil wells, and other sources can disturb them in ways we do not yet fully understand.'

I minimized changes to the factual content to ensure the questions associated with the text remain answerable. The simplification aims to make the text more accessible to learners of level B2 on the CEFR.<|eot_id|>

"EXERCISE IS GOOD FOR YOU Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel better and stay healthy. There are many reasons why you should exercise. It can help you lose weight, build strong muscles, and improve your posture. Exercise can also prevent injuries and improve your overall health. Did you know that exercise can even help with depression, tiredness, and stress? It can also help with certain medical conditions.

There are many types of exercise you can do, such as aerobics, jogging, and weightlifting. However, it's important to start slowly and carefully to avoid injury. It's also important to listen to your body and not overdo it.

Good posture is important for your overall health and appearance. Imagine a helium balloon attached to the top of your head, pulling you up towards the sky. This can help you stand up straight and breathe more easily. Stretching exercises can also improve your flexibility and prevent injuries.

To get the most out of exercise, it's important to warm up before you start, stretch during and after your workout, and cool down afterwards. This will help you stay safe and get the best results."

WHY FILM-MAKERS SPEND MONTHS IN THE WILDERNESS

Film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman travel to Africa for months at a time to make wildlife documentaries. They are not afraid of getting stuck in the mud or facing other challenges because they are passionate about their work. They have been working together for a long time and have developed a good understanding of each other's ideas.

Their latest project is about jackals, which are shy animals. They have to be patient and wait for the right moment to capture the perfect shot. They often spend weeks or even months in one place to get the footage they need.

Amanda and Owen work well together because they share the same vision and values. They want to make films that are not just informative but also emotional and engaging. They believe that if they can make people feel something, it's better than just teaching them facts.

In their daily routine, they make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask. They eat pre-packed meals and often go without a proper shower or laundry for weeks. But they are happy to make sacrifices because they love being in the wilderness and getting close to the animals.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of English at the B2 level:

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and does research on marine geochemistry, which is the study of the chemical processes in the sea. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she's not teaching, she goes on a special underwater journey. She gets into a small steel vehicle, like a small car, and dives 3 kilometers down to the ocean floor to study underwater volcanoes.

"It's very crowded inside," she says. "I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can take 16 hours - 3 hours to get down, 10 hours to collect samples, and 3 hours to get back up."

"If something goes wrong, there's an emergency button. The outside part of the vehicle opens, and a small escape boat comes out. It's like a ping-pong ball in a bathtub - it goes up quickly to the surface. Nobody has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team to a site west of the Canary Islands. There, they found a huge area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys spewing out black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive.

When she's not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love. I do it so I can focus on my research on underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and turns into black smoke. It's like a chimney, pouring out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was when I went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We stared at each other in silence, waiting. When it didn't happen, we were so relieved - we were still alive!"

"It's an amazing adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the window and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen them before. I studied underwater volcanoes for three years for my Ph.D. When I saw them for real, it was an incredible feeling."

Janet Goodwood, an administrative assistant, didn't get an interview for a promotion because the office manager thought she didn't fit the image of an office manager. The manager suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again.

Our body language and facial expressions also play a big role in making a good impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 55% of our message comes from our facial expressions, 38% from our voice, and only 7% from our words. Make sure your words match your body language to avoid confusing the interviewer.

It's also important not to show too much enthusiasm or eagerness for a job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, got a job offer on the spot, but her enthusiasm led the boss to offer her a lower salary than she expected. Finally, knowing about the company and preparing some questions to ask during the interview can make a big difference. David Artesio, a manager, suggests reading the company's annual report to learn about their activities and interests. Marian Woodall, a business consultant, recommends having a few short, clear questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences.

Meet Darius, Gabriel, Dieter, and Tomas, four young athletes who are passionate about their sports. Let's hear what they have to say about their lives.

I've always been into sports. I played many sports when I was younger, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I decided to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country's youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing. I train hard, both at home and abroad, to prepare for competitions. My goal is to compete in the next Olympics.

**Gabriel (surfer)**

The surfing community is small, so I see the same people wherever I compete. Professional surfers are very dedicated and often need to give up late-night parties to focus on their training. I don't mind too much, but I do love sleeping in and having a lie-in is usually not an option. However, it's worth it, as I won the National Championships last year and got to present a surfing series on TV. I do like to celebrate with a big night out after a win, especially if there's prize money involved.

**Dieter (yacht racer)**

When I'm on a boat with my teammates, we have a great time. We're a traditional group and like to celebrate our wins in style. We don't actively seek media attention, but sometimes reporters are more interested in where we go out to celebrate than our actual performance. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come back and do normal things with friends. I'm known within the sailing community, but I'm not a celebrity outside of it. I enjoy getting letters from fans and always reply to them.

**Tomas (tennis player)**

It's great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd's support. However, it can get chaotic sometimes. I do enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out and about, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. As a tennis player, I have to travel a lot, and that's why we split up. You have to make sacrifices in any sport, but I'm focusing on my game now and will catch up on other things when I retire.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B2 on the CEFR:

Taking children to the supermarket can be a difficult experience for some parents. Children often want everything they see, including the latest sugary cereals, Disney videos, and comics. Parents may feel guilty if they agree to their demands, knowing that they are buying unhealthy food. On the other hand, saying no can make them feel cross and defensive. Some parents try to avoid taking their children shopping, but this can also make them worry about not teaching their children how to make good choices.

Research shows that children make a purchase request every two minutes when they are with their parents in the supermarket. The food industry spends a lot of money on advertising, especially on TV, and this is likely to increase. Children often don't understand why their parents can't afford certain things, and they are easily swayed by attractive advertisements.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that parents are concerned about what they feed their children, but they may not always have accurate ideas about what is healthy. She believes that parents and children should have a conversation about food, but this can be difficult when children are bombarded with advertisements.

Some parents feel stressed when deciding what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says she tries to discuss food with her children and teaches them to read labels. She has found that this helps to reduce conflict in the supermarket.

Parents often admit that they are inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. One father says that he refuses to buy his son sweets because they are bad for him, but he buys unhealthy foods for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent and says that it depends on his mood.

Supermarkets could make shopping easier for parents by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. This could make parents more likely to shop without their children, which could actually attract more customers.

Here is the simplified version of the text, suitable for a B2 level learner:

**Ice Skating: A Fun and Challenging Activity**

Ice skating has a long history that dates back thousands of years. Archaeologists have found old skates made from animal bones. In the past, only the upper class in Scandinavia skated, but in the 1920s, a young figure skater named Sonja Henie popularized the sport and made it more accessible to everyone.

Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism. To start, it's important to focus on balance and control. As you gain experience, you can increase your speed. The position of your body is crucial for balance. Keep your knees slightly bent and your body weight centered. It's also essential to relax while skating, as it can be a physically demanding activity.

When you start, keep your heels together and your feet turned outwards. Push off with one foot while making a small movement with the other. As you get more comfortable, you can increase the length of your movements. It's also important to know how to fall safely. Even experienced skaters fall sometimes, but by relaxing your body, you can reduce the impact of the fall.

To get up after falling, kneel down and then stand up. Once you're confident on the ice, you can try different styles, such as figure skating, freestyle, or speed skating. It's best to start with figure skating and then move on to freestyle. Many ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn the basics.

To improve your skating, it's essential to practice regularly and do exercises to loosen up your body. This includes exercises for your legs, back, and shoulders, with a focus on your ankles and knees. After a long or intense skating session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness. Ice skating can improve your balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It's also a great way to stay healthy and fit, especially when combined with other activities like swimming or jogging.

Here is the simplified text for a learner of level B2:

It's true that we're all getting taller. Chris Greener, who is now Britain's tallest man at 228 cm, was already very tall when he was 14. In fact, the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade. This means that more and more people are growing taller. But this doesn't mean that we're becoming a new kind of superhuman. Instead, we're returning to what our ancestors were like thousands of years ago.

In the past, our ancestors ate a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, and meat. They even ate 85 different types of wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, people started farming, which had a big impact on our diet. Today, just three types of plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide most of the calories we need. This diet has had a negative effect on our health and physical development.

For a long time, people have been eating soups, porridges, and breads that are not very nutritious. This has led to problems like tooth decay and diseases. In one study, scientists found that when people started eating corn, they became unhealthy and underweight. However, farming allowed more people to live in the same area, which was a big advantage.

Now, some countries are trying to improve their diets and eat more like our ancestors did. As a result, the average height of people in some countries is increasing. But there are also some problems. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers are having to make new sizes all the time.

Scientists are trying to figure out how tall we can grow. Some think we might reach a maximum height of 193 cm, but others think we might start to shrink again because of global warming.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We love animals and enjoy their company. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work with exciting news. She had found a beautiful pine snake! "Can we keep it?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for temporary visitors, and I wanted to admire the snake and learn more about it.

I was running late, so I quickly boiled some water when I got home. But as I entered the bedroom, I heard screams from my sons. I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, chasing Bianca, a white mouse, around the room. The cat had the mouse's feet in its mouth and was trying to find a way out.

I joined the chaos and tripped over something. As I got up, I saw the snake had escaped from its tank and was slithering across the floor. I crouched down, ready to catch it, but it was too fast. The snake and I were both being jumped over by the cat, mouse, and kids, who were screaming and hissing. The dog was barking loudly.

I managed to catch the cat by the tail and freed the mouse from its mouth. The snake was still on the loose, so I looked for a way to catch it. It was very slippery, but I finally managed to pick it up and sit on the floor like a snake charmer. The snake relaxed and eventually allowed me to stand up and release it into the garden.

As I watched it go, my children and I stood in silence. Then my eldest son, DJ, explained, "You're nice and warm, Mum, and the shed isn't." I encouraged the kids to help the snake move away from the shed. It slowly slid up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of tail disappeared, my three-year-old son, Clay, said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

Taking children shopping can be very challenging for some mothers. They often want everything they see, especially sugary cereals, Disney videos, and comics. Mothers feel guilty when they agree to buy these things, but they also feel bad saying no. They worry that their children will not learn how to make their own choices. Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes while shopping. Advertisers spend a lot of money on TV ads targeting children, and this is likely to increase. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy them everything they want. They are influenced by attractive and persuasive ads, and parents' explanations about sugar and health are not convincing.

According to Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance, parents are concerned about what they feed their children, but their ideas about healthy food are not always accurate. Parents and children should have a dialogue about food, but TV ads give children a one-sided view. Parents feel like they are competing with advertisers and are forced to disappoint their children. The Independent Television Commission prohibits ads that tell children to ask their parents to buy something, but the intention is still to persuade children to ask for the product.

Some parents find it stressful to decide which demands to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she talks to her children about food and labels, and they have little conflict while shopping. Parents also admit they are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father, says he refuses to buy sweets for his son because they are bad for him, but he still buys treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent and sometimes says yes to his children's requests when he's feeling generous.

Supermarkets could help reduce parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas. This might encourage parents to shop without their children, which could attract more customers.

Here's the simplified text, adapted for a B2 level learner:

'Indoor climbing walls have become popular. Climbers used to go to mountains, but now they can climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd watches in awe as French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by his fingers at the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham. The National Indoor Arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events share something in common - The Wall. This is all thanks to a new technology. In the past, climbers would climb on cliffs in areas with good climbing angles. During the winter, they would either tolerate the cold or go walking instead. However, as the sport developed, top climbers needed to stay fit. When the cliffs were unusable, they used brick-edges or stone buildings to practice. This helped keep their fingers strong and prevented boredom. Many sports centres started building walls specifically for climbing, using bricks with special edges. These early walls were inspired by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He created a block of concrete with natural rock inside, which could be used in a wall. Many climbing walls were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s. However, these walls had limitations. They could only be built vertically, unlike cliffs, which have features like overhangs and angled rock. Climbers would eventually get bored with the repetitive nature of the walls. In 1985, a Frenchman, Francois Savigny, developed a material that could be moulded into shapes like those found on cliffs. This could be attached to any existing wall and removed when climbers got bored. French manufacturers also experimented with panels on steel frames. Steel frames could be built anywhere and were lighter than concrete, making it possible to create overhanging walls. A system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers an endless supply of new holds.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a B2 level learner:

Do you want to be an actor? When you tell someone you want to make a career in acting, they might say it's a risky choice. And it's true, there are many people who want to be actors, but there aren't as many jobs available. Some people might even think you're crazy for choosing this career. But it's a personal choice, and only you can decide if it's right for you.

Becoming an actor isn't easy. There are no exams to pass or a guaranteed way to succeed. It's a combination of luck and talent. However, there is always a demand for new actors and the possibility of exciting opportunities.

So, what makes someone talented? I believe it's a mix of natural ability and imagination. And it's not just about being good at acting, but also about being brave and believing in yourself.

Why do people want to act? For many, it's the thrill of performing in front of an audience. This connection with the audience is what drives actors to keep acting. Even experienced actors won't know exactly what makes them successful. They might know some things about themselves and their technique, but they always stay humble and know that they can't take anything for granted.

Actors also know that they can't control everything. They might be out of work one day and get a part the next. This uncertainty can be stressful, so they find ways to cope with the pressure. Nobody likes being rejected, and actors are no exception. From the moment they start looking for parts, they have to be prepared for rejection.

Ultimately, it's up to the actor to show they care about their craft and themselves. If they don't care, nobody else will.<|eot_id|>

To simplify the text for a learner of level B2, I will make some adjustments to the vocabulary, sentence structure, and complexity while maintaining the factual content. Here is the revised text:

Chris Greener, the tallest man in Britain, is 228 cm tall. When he was 14, he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be?" Chris replied, "The flagpole on a ship." The teacher had a point, as Chris was already quite tall at 14.

Every decade, the average height of Europeans increases by one centimetre. This means that more people are growing taller. However, this doesn't mean that humans are becoming a new species. Instead, we're returning to our natural height, similar to our ancestors who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, people ate a variety of foods, including fruits, vegetables, and animals. This diet was diverse and provided all the necessary nutrients. However, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming, which had negative consequences. Most of the land was used for farming, and only a few plants like wheat, rice, and maize provided most of our calories. This diet was not good for our health and physique.

As a result, people became underfed and underdeveloped. In one study, scientists found that when hunter-gatherers started eating corn, they became sickly and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was not a healthy food for humans.

Despite this, farming spread because it allowed more people to live on the same land. However, many people still rely on this system, which is not good for their health. Only in some countries like the US, Holland, and Japan are people eating a more diverse diet again, which has led to an increase in average height.

The average height in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a positive trend, but it also has its challenges. For example, beds and furniture are still the same size as they were 150 years ago, and clothes manufacturers have to constantly update their sizes.

The question is, where will our height stop growing? Will we reach a maximum height, and if so, what will it be? Some scientists think it could be as high as 193 cm, but others point out that as a species, we may be getting smaller due to climate change.

I hope this revised text is more suitable for level B2 learners.<|eot_id|>

All of these people changed their careers and are happy with their new lives. They learned to take risks and follow their dreams.'

'From childhood game to successful business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties, are sitting in their home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, playing a game that brings back memories of their childhood. The game is called pichenotte, which was introduced to their family by their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada. The family played the game every weekend and holiday, and it became a big part of their family tradition. When they moved to New Mexico, they continued to play, and visitors would often be fascinated by the game, which was unknown in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave decided to make a new pichenotte board, and it was a huge success. People loved the game, and soon the brothers were making more boards and selling them at markets and craft fairs. The game became very popular, and they even started a championship with a trophy called the Lord Pichenotte Cup. As the game's popularity grew, the brothers decided to turn their hobby into a business. They set up a workshop in their garage and started making more boards. So far, they have produced over 450 boards, which are made of birchwood and mahogany and are very durable.

The brothers sell their boards on their website for $595 each. While there are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, the brothers are hopeful that their business will continue to grow and make them successful.'

'Welcome to the Model Village! When I first saw this place, I couldn't believe it was once a piece of wasteland. For years, it was considered useless, but one man's hard work and his wife's support turned it into this beautiful village. Thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to create the landscape you see today. It took a lot of effort, with bulldozers and machines helping, but also many hours of manual labor.

To create the lawns, flowerbeds, and rockeries, we brought in about 1,000 tons of topsoil. We also planted hundreds of trees and shrubs, carefully choosing ones that could tolerate the salty air near the sea and strong winter winds. Some plants came from local nurseries, while others were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models over nine years. He used different materials like stone, concrete, and special wood to make the models durable. At first, he needed help from experts, but soon he became an expert himself.

You'll notice that everything is made to scale and that even the smallest details are carefully done. This took a lot of patience and developing special techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance.

The models you see are not based on specific buildings, but are typical British architectural styles. One of the most impressive is the Manor House, a 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls. As you walk around the village, you'll also see a castle, a church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths and don't touch the models, as this can cause damage. You're welcome to take photos from the paths only. Dogs are allowed on a short leash. To make your visit more enjoyable, you'll see buttons in front of some of the working models. Press these to make them operate.

We would love to hear your comments at the end of your visit. We're always planning new models and would appreciate any ideas you have. If you notice any models that aren't up to standard, please let us know. We're always updating and replacing models, so your feedback is important to us. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again soon. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!'

"Every week, British newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules of journalism. While some celebrities might pose for photographers, most people in the public eye suffer when their private moments are captured on the front page. However, very few people complain to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization that was set up to deal with such issues. Most of these pictures are not in the public interest. Do pictures of famous people help solve crimes? In what way did a recent picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC didn't investigate, which is a scandal. They should also investigate a recent story about a pop star's private life. The pop star didn't complain either. Shouldn't the PCC take the initiative and investigate other similar cases? This seems like a good idea at first, but there are many problems. The PCC would have to decide whether to launch an investigation and how to do it. They might have to approach the person involved and encourage them to complain. But if the person refuses, should the PCC still investigate? There are also practical problems. How could the PCC monitor all British newspapers and magazines? And what about the embarrassment factor? Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, do they really want an investigation? Most people just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might come out, and they don't want it to become public. In short, it's hard to find a solution to this serious problem."

This job will be important when you apply for your next job, as it will show that you have thought about your career and are committed to it. Most importantly, it should help you grow and develop as a person, and give you more responsibility.

If you're feeling restless and want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily while you're away, and then come back and find a new job. Employers will be impressed that you've had the experience and are not likely to get bored easily.

Juliette Davidson, for example, worked for three solicitors after leaving college. She had a good experience, but there was no room for advancement. So, she left and traveled for a year. Now, she works as a Personal Assistant to the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says that in just two and a half years, she's become more confident and her job has changed a lot. She's taken on more responsibilities, such as doing correspondence and budgets, and even gets involved in important projects and events.

During the Easter holidays, children can take part in a fun quiz at the Gallery. The quiz sheets are available at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be asked to find 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz sheets are available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

New Picture

The Gallery has a beautiful still life painting by a Dutch artist from the 18th century. The painting is of flowers and fruit and is very colorful. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. The artist waited for certain flowers to bloom before painting them. The painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister. You can see it in Room 25.

Special Exhibition

The exhibition 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century' opened on 15 March. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters from this period. The exhibition will run until 31 May.

Lectures

There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez, and on 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

Gallery Restaurant

The Gallery restaurant has improved and expanded its service. It now offers a wide range of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

Visitor Information

Guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's most famous paintings and give an overview of its collection of European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.'

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B2 on the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR):

'Money What is money? Money is like a unit of measurement, just like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. A £5 note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that doesn't cost much to make. A long time ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Instead, people would trade things with each other. For example, a farmer might exchange the corn he grew for some honey from a beekeeper. This was a simple exchange between two people who had something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own systems of money so that people could trade more easily. As different systems joined together, we now use a national currency.'

Hypatia: The First Woman Scientist

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 AD. For a long time, she was the only woman scientist to be remembered in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University and made sure she got the best education available. This was unusual because most women didn't have many opportunities to study at that time. Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome before returning to Alexandria, where she started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. Although we don't have copies of her books, we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented some scientific tools to help her with her work. Unfortunately, many rulers at that time were afraid of science, and people connected with it were in danger. One day, in March 415, Hypatia was attacked and killed in the street.

Although the train didn't live up to all the promises, it took me to some of Australia's most amazing sights."

'Climbing Ben Nevis in Scotland is a popular activity. Many people climb the mountain every year. Ben Nevis is a big mountain, and the weather can be very cold because it's located in the north. Climber Keith Hewitt describes his first time climbing Ben Nevis in winter.

In February, Keith and his group decided to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This is a long climb, about 600 metres up. They planned to camp for three days on the way. They brought tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for their boots because the snow was very hard and slippery.

Although some members of the group were experienced climbers, they took all the necessary safety equipment, including lights, hard hats, and extra clothing. The weather forecast was good, but they were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge.

The track was steep, and Keith's legs felt heavy. He had to rest more often than the others because he was not as experienced. The group waited for him to catch up, but then they continued climbing. Keith realized that he should train more before climbing in the future.

After climbing for 200 metres, they reached the beginning of Tower Ridge, a narrow path that takes you to the top of the mountain. The path is only 1.5 metres wide, and the mountain drops away on both sides. They had to be careful and concentrate as they walked along it. It took them seven hours to reach the top.

From the top, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. However, on this day, there was a mist, so they couldn't see very far. Climbing down the mountain can be just as challenging as climbing up. You need to be able to read a map correctly to avoid taking a wrong turn. Keith was relieved that they took turns reading the map to ensure they got back to camp safely. Keith only felt like he really enjoyed the experience when he was safely in his tent. He was glad he made it to the top.'

Right now, we're preparing for a new production, and I'm going to take part in a competition for young dancers. I feel very lucky to be here.

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a learner of level B2 on the CEFR:

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, people went to the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice to themselves. In the late 1980s, someone had an idea to use the winter for something special. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to create an art exhibition in a special igloo in a small town called Jukkasjarvi, near the frozen Torne River. The igloo, called Arctic Hall, was a big success and many people came to visit.

One night, a group of visitors had the idea to sleep in the igloo. They were very happy with their experience and this idea led to the creation of the ICEHOTEL. Today, it's a famous hotel all around the world.

Every year, a team of builders, architects, and artists come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They use natural materials like snow and ice to build it. The hotel is finished in parts, and each part opens to visitors and guests as it's completed. The first part is finished in December, and then a new part opens every week until January 7th.

Since the hotel is built outside, the finishing date depends on the weather. In the spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, it's never colder than -5°C to -8°C, even if it's very cold outside. Guests are provided with warm clothing, but it's a good idea to bring extra warm clothes, like sweaters and socks.

The hotel is located in Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. It's close to Kiruna airport and train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the hotel.

**The Short Story Society**

The Short Story Society helps writers in the UK. It was founded in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in the country.

**Our Magazines**

We publish several excellent magazines. One of them is the Short Story Review, which features short stories by well-known British writers and provides opportunities for new writers to get published. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about writing events, competitions, and festivals.

**National Short Story Competition**

We run a national short story competition that is open to anyone over 18. The competition is from April to October each year. There is no entry fee for members, but non-members have to pay £5. The best stories will be published in our annual book, and the winner will get a publishing contract.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, we have worked with schools, helping children and teachers develop their writing skills. We also have a competition for young writers aged 11-18, where the winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day writing course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

Our Writers' Cafe is a relaxed and stylish place where you can read our magazines, enjoy vegetarian food and drinks, and attend events like exhibitions, courses, and readings. It's located in the heart of London and is open from 11am to 10pm Monday to Friday and 11am to 8pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Joining the Society**

We have members from all over the world. If you're interested in joining, you can fill out a registration form on our website.

As a well-known person, Tanya thinks people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. In the future, Tanya plans to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at the age of 25 and doesn't plan to stop for many years.'

'Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the city of Albuquerque in the south-western United States becomes a kaleidoscope of colours in the sky. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that has been running for over 40 years. The first festival was held in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, there were just a dozen hot-air balloons. Today, over a thousand balloons from around the world attend the festival.

What to see and do

During the festival, the pilots of the hot-air balloons communicate with each other and simultaneously light up their burners, creating a spectacular sight known as a 'balloon glow'. This is a great opportunity to take amazing photos. However, you need to arrive at the festival site just before sunset or early in the morning to see the balloons take off in the dark sky.

During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in all shapes and sizes, with some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, and even popular brands. Kids will love it!

You can also take a ride in a hot-air balloon over the desert or ride a cable car to the top of the nearby mountains for a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other activities for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks displays.

Practical tips

Buy your tickets online in advance to avoid long queues. Wear layers of thin clothing, as it can be cool in the evening and early morning, but hot during the day. Bring a flashlight for night-time events, a camera, and suncream. If you're not a digital photographer, bring high-speed film for evening and night-time photos.'

* Added more concrete and descriptive language to help learners visualize the festival

Here is the simplified text, adapted for a level B2 learner:

'History of Shoes

In the past, people didn't think about making shoes comfortable or fashionable. They wore animal skins to keep their feet warm in cold weather. We still use leather today, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton. It wasn't until about 150 years ago that people started wearing a different shoe on each foot. Before that, people wore the same type of shoe on both feet. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most are made in big factories using machines. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry produce many more shoes at a lower cost, making them more affordable for more people.'

Here is the simplified text for a B2 level learner:

THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD

In the late 1800s, people came to Alaska to search for gold. One town that grew quickly was Iditarod, which means 'far away place'. In the summer, supplies could be delivered by boat, but in the winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to get to the towns. So, in 1910, a winter road was built for dog teams to travel along. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. The road became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took three weeks for the dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s, when planes replaced dog teams as the main way to travel. However, the dogs got one last big job in 1925. A disease called diphtheria spread to the city of Nome, and the closest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. The only pilot who could fly in the cold weather was away, so it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey was over 1,000 km, most of it along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to complete the journey. The medicine was delivered, and the diphtheria was stopped. One of the dogs, Balto, became a hero for saving the team from icy water. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the same route as that famous journey. It's called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

I made the following changes to simplify the text:

* Simplified vocabulary and sentence structures
* Removed some technical terms and jargon
* Reduced the amount of detail and focused on the main events
* Changed some complex sentences into simpler ones
* Removed some of the more advanced vocabulary and replaced it with simpler alternatives<|eot_id|>

When we're over Antarctica, feel free to get up and move around the plane to see the sights.

What if the weather is bad? We have 17 different flight plans and our captain chooses the best one based on the satellite weather forecast. Can I see penguins and other wildlife? Unfortunately, most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, so we can't see them in detail. We don't land on Antarctica for environmental reasons. 'Winter Driving: Be Careful on the Roads

Winter driving can be risky because it's hard to predict what will happen and accidents can happen quickly. Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and ice can be hidden under the snow, waiting to cause an accident. A car coming towards you might also slide across the road. To stay safe, follow two important rules.

First, drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. Imagine you're driving with a cup of hot coffee next to you - drive slowly and carefully so you don't spill it.

Second, be aware of what might happen. On icy roads, you need to look further ahead than usual. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be going faster than you think. When the road is wet, snowy, or icy, leave more space between you and the car in front. Try to stay in control of your car at all times and you'll avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison was a Scottish painter. He went to London to study law, but ended up at art school instead. He didn't enjoy the traditional drawing classes, but continued to paint. In his late 20s, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. This is where he developed an interest in early Italian artists, which is reflected in some of his work. He loved the green and brown colours of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this in his paintings. To achieve this, he paints thin layers of colour on top of each other, from light to dark. He claims he never knows what the final result will be. 'It's a secret,' he says, 'because I don't know myself.'

Aitchison believes that anyone can learn to mix colours. 'You can buy the colours,' he says. 'I just notice what colours go well together.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make sketches before starting a painting. He thinks that if he did, he might lose interest in the painting. Instead, he makes many changes to his paintings before they're finished. This is why he prefers to work with models who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I think they're worried and want to see the painting, I can't work,' he says.

Aitchison has lived in London for many years, but he doesn't feel part of the Scottish art scene. He doesn't want to follow any particular style or tradition, he just paints the way he wants to. Despite this, his work has influenced many young British artists.<|eot_id|>

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world. Before she did it, she was a journalist and lived in a small flat in London. In 1993, she decided to leave her job and family to travel to Asia with some other climbers. She found that climbing Everest was very challenging. The next spring, Bill waited for the birds to return. But they didn't come back. So Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks, but couldn't find them. In the past, London didn't have a police force. A few old men used to look after the streets at night, but they weren't paid much. London was a big city with many poor people and a lot of crime. People were afraid to go out at night because of thieves. In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding started paying a group of people to stop thieves. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force was created with 3000 officers. Most of them walked, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all police officers in London were men. Today, London police are well paid, and police officers who still ride horses get paid even more.'

Gail Rollins is a well-known runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run in the 10,000 and 5,000 meter races at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was often second in big competitions, but she always smiled and laughed about it. People in her hometown love her for her positive attitude. However, everything changed in 2004 when she won her first half-marathon, a very long road race. She finished in a very good time, the fastest for any British woman runner that year. Gail's husband and manager, Mike Rollins, used to be a runner too, but he had to stop due to an injury. Now, he sometimes runs with Gail, but she always leaves him behind. Gail trains hard. She goes for a long run in the morning and then does some fast runs in the afternoon. She takes a rest from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I'm with her all the time. Sometimes I ask if she should eat something, like cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2,500 km/h. This means that the journey from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by plane, and it's hard to imagine a world without them.'
